author: By Charles Homans and Mark Peterson
title: How ‘Stop the Steal’ Captured the American Right
description: The movement to reinstate President Trump has gone far beyond him — and now threatens the future of American elections.
content: The Pennsylvania State Capitol, in Harrisburg, is a Beaux-Arts landmark that on its eastern side echoes the west terrace of the U.S. Capitol, and the scene there on Nov. 7, 2020, four days after Election Day, strikingly prefigured the one in Washington two months later. On the plaza below, more than a thousand strong, were the Donald Trump faithful, in MAGA hats and every possible variation of red, white and blue clothing, waving the banners of the campaign. “Stop the steal!” they chanted. “Stop the steal!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Questions About An Unsolved Murder Linger Over ‘Where the Crawdads Sing’
description: The release of a movie based on the best-selling novel renewed questions about the author, Delia Owens, her time in Zambia and the shooting of a suspected poacher there.
content: When Delia Owens, a retired wildlife biologist, released her novel “Where the Crawdads Sing” in 2018, no one anticipated a blockbuster. Owens, who is in her early 70s, had never published fiction before. Her publisher printed a modest run of 28,000 hardcover copies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Dog Helps Rescue Owner Who Fell 70 Feet in California Forest
description: Saul, a black Border collie, helped lead search and rescue crews to his owner, who the authorities said had broken his hip and multiple ribs after falling from a ridge.
content: A 53-year-old man and his black Border collie, Saul, were on a hike last week near California’s Tahoe National Forest, surrounded by trees and steep canyons, when something went wrong. The man fell 70 feet from a ridge, breaking his hip and multiple ribs, the authorities said. He had no phone. Just a dog by his side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Wales breaks temperature records.
content: Temperatures in Britain neared a record high yesterday as blistering heat swept the country. By midafternoon, Wales had recorded its highest-ever temperature: The thermometer hit 37.1 degrees Celsius, almost 99 degrees Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: The Midterm Races That Give Democrats Nightmares
description: A new poll offers fodder for both parties to claim that voters are on their side in crucial secretary of state elections. Who’s right?
content: Professional Democrats have many fears about the 2022 midterm elections that keep them up at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Lizzo’s Empowerment Pop Gets Stuck in the Same Groove
description: “Special,” her second major-label album, gestures toward complexities that would broaden her image as the queen of the mirror pep talk, but retreats to her comfort zone.
content: Since her charismatic breakout hit “Truth Hurts” dominated the Hot 100 in 2019, the music of the Houston-raised singer, rapper, songwriter and flutist Lizzo has been a pop cultural omnipresence — a glossy sonic lacquer ready to provide any humdrum moment with a hater-repellent sheen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: ‘Late Show’ Staff Arrested at U.S. Capitol Complex Won’t Be Prosecuted
description: The Justice Department said it would not proceed with charges of unlawful entry against staff members from “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” who were arrested at a Capitol building last month.
content: Federal prosecutors said late Monday that they would not prosecute staff members of “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” who were arrested last month at the United States Capitol complex on charges of unlawful entry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: New York City Opens Cooling Centers as It Braces for a Heat Wave
description: With Wednesday and Thursday forecast to reach highs of 100 degrees, cooling centers are scheduled to open to offer the public relief from the heat.
content: As New Yorkers brace for a week of extremely hot weather, cooling centers in air-conditioned buildings throughout the city will be open to the public from Tuesday through Thursday to offer relief from the heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: After Heavy Rains, a Sinkhole Opens in the Bronx
description: The hole appeared on Monday night, damaging a water main and swallowing a parked van.
content: A sinkhole appeared in the Bronx on Monday as rain and high winds rolled through New York City, growing throughout the evening and swallowing a parked van.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Putin Finds a New Ally in Iran, a Fellow Outcast
description: A three-way summit meeting in Tehran between the leaders of Russia, Iran and Turkey sent a clear signal that Vladimir Putin is pushing back against ostracism from the West.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin left Russia for a rare international trip on Tuesday and received a handsome reward: a meeting with a prominent world leader who voiced a full-throated endorsement for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Zixu Wang
title: ‘My Worldview Has Been Destroyed’: Chinese Banking Scandal Tests Faith in the System
description: The disappearance of ordinary savers’ money, and the government’s seemingly indifferent response, could pose a major test for the Communist Party’s legitimacy.
content: BEIJING — The saving opportunity with the rural bank in central China looked, to Sun Song, a 26-year-old-businessman, like a great find. It would be linked to his existing account at a large, reputable state-owned bank. The rural bank was also offering high interest rates, making it seem like an ideal place to park his roughly $600,000 in savings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: ‘We Were So Blindsided’: What New Parents Should Know About Parechovirus
description: Health officials warn that this common, but little-known, virus can pose a lethal threat to infants.
content: About two weeks after he was born, Kat DeLancy’s son, Ronan, became fussy and stopped eating as well as he had been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Effortless Way to Style a Coffee Table
description: Designers and home stagers make it look so easy. Here’s how they do it.
content: A coffee table isn’t just a place for your guests to set down their drinks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: 3 Ways Musk Can Support Free Speech
description: If Elon Musk buys Twitter, there are steps he could take to expand the boundaries of online expression.
content: Way back in the Paleolithic age of April, Elon Musk seemed excited to buy Twitter and said that he wanted to transform the site by promoting free speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Amid Campaign Revamp, Herschel Walker Stumps Without a Stumble
description: After a string of damaging reports, and briefly shunning publicity, the Republican Senate candidate was out on the trail again in rural Georgia.
content: OCILLA, Ga. — Herschel Walker, Georgia’s Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate, gave a 10-minute stump speech on Tuesday in which he told no new whoppers, made no obvious mistakes and allowed reporters to witness the whole thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Beggs
title: ‘Porn of the Self’: Novels of Female Angst
description: Cocktails, an addiction to erotica, workplace harassment and more.
content: Eighteen-year-old Raizl hiding her laptop beneath her covers while she basks in the glow of endless, muted porn is a picture burned into my memory as permanently as the shvantzes and shmundies are in the protagonist’s imagination (look them up). Felicia Berliner’s SHMUTZ (260 pp., Atria, $27) is about a young woman with a porn addiction that’s somehow even more forbidden than most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Bigger Than Trump
description: Why election conspiracy theories have become central to the Republican Party.
content: On Feb. 24, 2016 — during Donald Trump’s Republican primary campaign and more than four years before he would falsely accuse Joe Biden of election fraud — somebody registered the website www.stopthesteal.org. It may have been Roger Stone, the Republican operative who was advising Trump’s 2016 campaign and appears to have coined the phrase “Stop the Steal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Coral Davenport and Elena Shao
title: Trying to Salvage His Climate Agenda, Biden Weighs Remaining Options
description: With his legislative plan for global warming in shreds, the president has come under pressure to use all other tools at his disposal.
content: President Biden will travel Wednesday to a shuttered coal-fired power plant that is now part of an offshore wind project in Massachusetts, where he is expected to deliver remarks on clean energy as his administration scrambles to salvage its climate agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: A cameraman became an accidental obstacle in the men’s steeplechase
description: Soufiane El Bakkali of Morocco, the reigning Olympic champion, won the race.
content: Steeplechasers are familiar with obstacles. Over the course of 3,000 meters, they must clear 28 waist-high barriers and seven water pits. On Monday night, though, in the early stages of the men’s final, they found themselves contending with a different sort of obstacle: a cameraman who had wandered onto the track.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kharkiv Tried to Return to Normal. Russian Shelling Wouldn’t Let It.
description: Ukraine repelled the effort to capture its second-largest city, but the artillery attacks did not stop. Many residents who left have returned but fear that a new offensive is imminent.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Alina Titova fell to her knees on the steps of the central railway station at her first glimpse of her home city after arriving back on the train.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: How Penguins Beat the Heat and Went South
description: Scientists reconstructed some of the evolutionary steps that led penguins to quit tropical climates for the Antarctic life over millions of years.
content: Few animals have evolved to survive the unforgiving Antarctic like penguins. Species like the emperor penguin have overlapping layers of insulating plumage, tightly packed veins to recycle body heat and just enough paunch to weather wind chills that approach minus 80 degrees Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi and Alan Feuer
title: Bannon ‘Decided He Was Above the Law,’ Prosecutor Says
description: The jury in Stephen K. Bannon’s contempt of Congress trial is being asked a simple question: Did he defy the House panel investigating the Jan. 6 attack by ignoring a subpoena?
content: WASHINGTON — After weeks of legal wrangling and heated speeches on the courthouse steps, the criminal trial of Stephen K. Bannon, a onetime aide to former President Donald J. Trump, opened on Tuesday as prosecutors told the jury they would have to answer a simple question: Did Mr. Bannon defy the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol by blatantly ignoring a subpoena?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Why Housing Is So Expensive — Particularly in Blue States
description: The urban economist Jenny Schuetz breaks down America’s housing crises, the policies that could fix them and the politics standing in the way.
content: America is experiencing a housing crisis — or, more accurately, multiple housing crises. A massive housing shortage in major cities has resulted in skyrocketing rents. Low- and middle-income individuals find themselves priced out of the places with the most opportunity. Homelessness is rampant in cities across the country. Developers often face the steepest obstacles to building in the places where new housing is needed most. And young people are increasingly viewing homeownership, once a vital part of the American dream, as hopelessly out of reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. Women Beat Canada to Claim Spot in Paris Olympics
description: The Americans’ victory in the final of the Concacaf W Championship avenged a bitter loss to the Canadians at last summer’s Tokyo Olympics.
content: The symmetry would not have been lost on any of them: the United States and Canada, two of the world’s best women’s soccer teams, meeting on a sweltering night and chasing a prize only one of them could win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Spigariol and Jack Nicas
title: Bolsonaro Gathers Foreign Diplomats to Cast Doubt on Brazil’s Elections
description: President Jair Bolsonaro elevated his vote-fraud claims from a matter of domestic politics to foreign policy, heightening international fears that he would dispute the coming election.
content: BRASÍLIA — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil called dozens of foreign diplomats to the presidential palace on Monday to tell them that he believed the country’s voting systems could be rigged, a potential preview of his strategy for an election that is 75 days away and that polls forecast he will lose in a landslide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: What to Watch For in Tuesday’s Primary Elections in Maryland
description: There are close contests in the Democratic and Republican primaries for governor, and in a few House races as the dust settles from redistricting. But the winners could take days to be called.
content: Marylanders are the only voters going to the polls on Tuesday, choosing major-party candidates for governor and the House of Representatives in the November midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Wherever Juan Soto Goes, Remarkable Things Tend to Happen
description: After being grilled about turning down a $440 million contract, Soto won the Home Run Derby. All in a day’s work.
content: LOS ANGELES — It takes remarkable self-assurance to turn down $440 million. No baseball player has ever earned that much in a single contract. Most people would eagerly sign, but Juan Soto, the outfield marvel for the Washington Nationals, said no. Even within the small galaxy of major league superstars, he stands out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: ‘History Is Everything’: Making a Film About Black Maternal Mortality
description: The directors Paula Eiselt and Tonya Lewis Lee discuss their journey in making the documentary “Aftershock,” which shines a light on a national health crisis.
content: “Black lives matter because Black wombs matter!” Shawnee Benton Gibson chanted from the stage during a National Action Network rally in Washington, D.C., in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: ISIS Fighters’ Children Are Growing Up in a Desert Camp. What Will They Become?
description: Leaving captured men, women and children in prisons and camps run by Kurds risks seeding a new global terrorism disaster, rights groups and the U.S. military warn.
content: AL HOL, Syria — Viewed from a helicopter, this enormous camp that holds the wives and children of dead or captured Islamic State fighters was a sea of white tents against the desolate landscape of drought-stricken northeastern Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: He Fought Boston’s Blue Wall of Silence. Now He’s the Commissioner.
description: Boston’s new police commissioner, Michael Cox, was the victim of an assault by fellow officers who mistook him for a suspect.
content: BOSTON — Before dawn on a January morning in 1995, the phone rang in the home of Michael A. Cox Sr., a Boston police officer. His wife answered, still groggy. He had been hurt. As two of his fellow officers rushed her to the emergency room, she asked what had happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: On Sweltering New York Day, Rockaway Beaches Close Over Shark Sightings
description: As temperatures in the city climbed into the 90s this week, all of Rockaway’s beaches were closed for swimming because of shark sightings.
content: As temperatures in Queens climbed into the 90s, Rockaway’s beaches were closed on Tuesday afternoon for swimming because of shark sightings, officials said, leaving only the boardwalk open for beachgoers on the hot day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justine van der Leun
title: After Truth and Reconciliation? Their Lives.
description: Eve Fairbanks’s decades-spanning portrait addresses three experiences of the “New South Africa.”
content: The journalist Eve Fairbanks’s sweeping work of narrative reportage, “The Inheritors,” opens in a shack in Soweto. There, a girl named Malaika, who has grown up in the “New South Africa,” readies herself for her daily two-hour morning journey from her township to school. Malaika’s mother fought for her daughter to have a better life, but now, as Malaika walks past trash piles and coal fires and boards the city bus at dawn, she wonders: What does such a life look like?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Spanish Authorities Seize a ‘Contraband’ Picasso at Ibiza Airport
description: Investigators said they found a 1966 work called “Trois Personnages” when they searched a passenger’s luggage.
content: Officials in Spain seized a drawing believed to be by Pablo Picasso valued at more than $460,000 from a passenger who failed to declare it to airport customs, the Tax Agency and Civil Guard in Spain said in a statement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Mourning Technoblade: Fans Grieve a Minecraft Star They Never Met
description: The expert gamer built a following of millions of mostly young players on YouTube, without revealing his name or face.
content: Late last month, more than 10.4 million subscribers to a YouTube channel received a notification that usually brought good news: Technoblade, an expert Minecraft player, had posted a new video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Is on Edge Waiting for Russia to Restart the Gas on Nord Stream 1
description: A maintenance shutdown of the pipeline, the main artery between Russia and Germany, is expected to end later this week amid heightened tensions.
content: Months of brinkmanship by Russia over the flow of natural gas to Germany and the rest of Europe could reach a high point later this week, when a temporary shutdown of the Nord Stream 1 pipeline is scheduled to end.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Just Like Me, but Hotter’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: After a terrible year (I was attacked in my home then suffered through a difficult divorce), my elderly parents visited and helped me pull the ivy that had swallowed my backyard. My father said, “Don’t let that take over again, Irene.” Ten years later, while grappling with stubborn regrowth, I found dad’s hat — gnarled, mouse nibbled, rotted. I’d been missing him fiercely, wishing he were still here to guide me. Not one for assigning spiritual meaning to coincidence, I’ll take this particular tap on the shoulder. Thanks for taking care of me, dad. I’ll take care of the ivy. — Irene Ziegler
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jenny Schuetz
description: The July 19, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jenny Schuetz. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘A Dark, Dark Man’ Review: Murder and Corruption in Kazakhstan
description: This exceptionally grim police procedural recalls films like Bong Joon Ho’s “Memories of Murder” and Nuri Bilge Ceylan’s “Once Upon a Time in Anatolia.”
content: “A Dark, Dark Man” is set in a stretch of Kazakhstan where few people seem to live, yet corruption pervades every corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Hayley Kiyoko Revs Up With Arcade Fire and Chills Out to ‘Friends’
description: The pop singer and songwriter has been doing some emotional spring cleaning as she prepares to release her second full-length album, “Panorama.”
content: The pop singer and songwriter Hayley Kiyoko’s fans call her “lesbian Jesus,” and she’s become known for boldly and unapologetically putting every facet of herself into her artistry. That wasn’t always the case, however.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: British homes were built to retain heat. That’s becoming a problem.
description: Keeping homes cool in the country’s typically mild summers was never a priority.
content: For generations, homes in Britain were designed to retain heat, to make cold winters bearable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Why Russia Believes It Cannot Lose the War in Ukraine
description: An interview with Sergey Karaganov.
content: Sergey Karaganov is a prominent Russian political scientist whom I have known for almost 20 years in covering Russia and have interviewed many times as a window into Kremlin thinking. The academic director of the faculty of World Economy and International Affairs at Moscow’s Higher School of Economics and honorary chairman of Russia’s premier nongovernmental think tank, Mr. Karaganov warned for years about a potential conflict in Ukraine over NATO expansion. Since the brutal Russian invasion of Ukraine began in February, he has written articles and given interviews in broad support of President Vladimir Putin, so I interviewed him to better understand Mr. Putin’s aims in the conflict. Ukraine continues to suffer, and those who hope to support Ukraine must understand those aims as it tries to confront Russia’s aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: France Will Spend Nearly $10 Billion to Renationalize Electricity Company
description: The government offered to buy the shares it doesn’t already own in EDF, which operates all of the country’s nuclear plants, in the face of a worsening energy crisis after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: France plans to pay 9.7 billion euros, about $9.8 billion, to fully renationalize EDF, the state-backed electricity giant, in a move that the government said would allow it to bolster the country’s energy independence, overhaul its nuclear power program and invest in renewables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: ‘Crisis and Decline’: Report Paints a Bleak Assessment of Australia’s Environment
description: Climate change, habitat loss, invasive species, pollution and mining have contributed to a drastic decline in the populations of some wildlife species.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Australia’s environment and wildlife are facing even greater threats than previously acknowledged, according to a new report that the environment minister said painted a “story of crisis and decline.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Sneed
title: Do Eye Creams Actually Work for Wrinkles?
description: Look for a few key ingredients in skin care products if you want to deal with wrinkles — but no product will keep your face crease free.
content: Q: Does eye cream really prevent wrinkles?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Facing Tepid Support, Bill de Blasio Drops N.Y. House Bid
description: Polls showed Mr. de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City who also prematurely ended a 2020 presidential bid, trailing in a crowded Democratic primary.
content: Bill de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City, abruptly ended a campaign for Congress on Tuesday, saying that voters were clearly “looking for another option” and that his time in electoral politics was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin Visits Iran
description: Also, a banking scandal disrupts China and Spain debates a wind farm off its coast.
content: Vladimir Putin, Russia’s president, visited Iran on Tuesday, underscoring how the war in Ukraine has altered the world’s geopolitics by helping to align two regional powers that have been isolated from Europe and the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Iran Backs the War
description: In Tehran, Iran’s supreme leader gives Putin a strong endorsement.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Baker
title: What Baby Boomers Want (Options!), Senior Housing Delivers
description: Shifting demographics are reshaping complexes built for older Americans, who are looking for a variety of rates and services.
content: The pandemic crushed the senior housing market, cutting occupancy rates and stalling construction. Now, as the market begins an uneven rebound, developers are adapting to the coming wave of aging baby boomers with a new crop of living developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliot Ackerman
title: The Echoes and Echoes and Echoes of War
description: In his new story collection, “The Haunting of Hajji Hotak,” Jamil Jan Kochai explores the intergenerational impact of conflict.
content: Violence — whether between individuals or between nations — has a long, intergenerational tail. It haunts the lives of those who witnessed, participated in or fell victim to that violence, and it haunts their descendants. Jamil Jan Kochai is one of those descendants. He was born to Afghan refugees in a camp in Peshawar, Pakistan, after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, and migrated to the United States as a child. He is currently a Stegner fellow at Stanford University, and his first novel, “99 Nights in Logar,” was an interconnected series of stories with the war as a backdrop. His debut story collection is also about war, but it’s about family, too, and how each generation forges its own stories in the wake of the generation that preceded it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: A Behind-the-Scenes Eminence Shapes a Festival’s Future
description: Pierre Audi, the artistic director of the Park Avenue Armory, is coming into his own as the leader of the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France.
content: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — On a recent Monday afternoon, the Grand Théâtre de Provence here was almost empty, a few hours before a concert performance of Monteverdi’s opera “L’Orfeo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Day the Music Died’ Review: ‘American Pie,’ the Life of a Hit
description: Don McLean tries to clear up some misapprehensions about the eight-an-a-half-minute song that took on a life of its own, in this documentary.
content: Even those who don’t like Don McLean’s song “American Pie” have to admit that it’s a distinctive pop culture achievement. A nearly eight-and-a-half minute allegory that goes from mournful to infectious to mournful again, the monster 1971 radio hit is seemingly known to all generations and still sung at bar-closing times the world over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami
title: Migrants in Morocco Are Sentenced in Attempt to Cross Into Spanish Enclave
description: Thirty-three men, part of a larger group, were given 11 months in prison after a deadly border-crossing effort.
content: PARIS — A judge in the northeastern Moroccan city of Nador sentenced 33 migrants to 11 months in prison on Tuesday and ordered them to pay small fines in connection with a mass attempt to cross into the Spanish enclave of Melilla last month, defense lawyers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Students Are Learning Well Again. But Full Recovery? That’s a Long Way Off.
description: A new report estimates that it may take students at least three to five years to recover from the pandemic. Federal relief money will most likely have run out by then.
content: After the coronavirus pandemic sent a jolt through the American education system, interrupting the learning of millions of children, a new report offers a glimmer of hope: By the end of the last school year, many students had returned to a normal pace of academic growth for the first time since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: ‘Law & Order’ Crew Member Is Fatally Shot at Brooklyn Film Location
description: The man, who was enforcing parking restrictions on a Greenpoint block before filming began on Tuesday, was sitting in a car when he was killed by a lone gunman.
content: A Brooklyn film location for a ripped-from-the-headlines television crime show became a murder scene early Tuesday when a man who was enforcing parking restrictions connected to the production was fatally shot while he sat in a car, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Emily Schmall, Skandha Gunasekara and Atul Loke
title: Out of Cash and Out of Fuel, Sri Lanka Runs on Patience
description: The rage at the failure and corruption of a ruling elite is matched by generosity and ingenuity to prevent complete collapse and anarchy.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The queues are ubiquitous — and orderly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: One of America’s Most Seductive States Is Also One of Its Scariest
description: North Carolina holds an illuminating — and alarming — political mirror up to the country.
content: CLAYTON, N.C. — For a tidy snapshot of our messy country, you could do worse than North Carolina’s newly redrawn 13th Congressional District, where suburb yields to exurb and fields of tobacco and sweet potatoes somehow hold their ground. I had to drive only 15 miles of it to see two versions of America — and to see them at war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Words of War: A Literary Lifeline for the Battlefield
description: Does poetry have any place in a war zone? For one correspondent, it is indispensable.
content: Even the newest of correspondents knows not to go into a war zone without the right training, the right gear and the right exit plan. But some seasoned reporters have learned that they need something more to sustain them through the bleak days and nights of carnage. Something to remind them of the humanity beneath the inhumanity. For some, it is poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
title: Firefighters battle an ‘explosive cocktail’ of wind and flames in southwestern France.
description: More than 2,000 firefighters are trying to contain raging wildfires that have burned nearly 80 square miles of vegetation and forced thousands to evacuate.
content: LA TESTE-DE-BUCH, France — More than 2,000 firefighters from around France were battling raging wildfires on Tuesday that have burned nearly 80 square miles of parched forest in the Gironde area of the country’s southwest and forced over 37,000 people to evacuate in the past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Claes Oldenburg Captured a Carefree (and Consumerist) America
description: Even viewers who did not know the artist’s name devoured his audacious sculptures of cheeseburgers, cherries and ice cream cones.
content: Of all the major American Pop artists, Claes Oldenburg was the only one who was born in Europe. He was still in grade school when his father, a Swedish diplomat, moved the family to this country. They settled in Chicago, a city that has a much-lauded architectural history and calls itself, not unjustly, the birthplace of the skyscraper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Plotting the Future of the Most Storied Studio in Jazz
description: The New Jersey recording space built in 1959 by Rudy Van Gelder is filled with history. Can it regain its glory without getting stuck in the past?
content: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J. — Hidden along a commercial strip north of the George Washington Bridge, surrounded by car dealerships and characterless corporate offices, is hallowed ground for jazz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: Trump Electors Targeted in Georgia Criminal Inquiry
description: A prosecutor in Atlanta is investigating interference in the 2020 presidential election, an inquiry that has engulfed Donald J. Trump and many of his allies.
content: Prosecutors in Atlanta have informed 16 Trump supporters who formed an alternate slate of 2020 presidential electors from Georgia that they could face charges in an ongoing criminal investigation into election interference, underscoring the risk of criminal charges that Donald J. Trump and many of his allies may be facing in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Camp
title: When We Consent, We Shouldn’t Feel Terrible After, Right?
description: We deserve more than sex that is merely legal.
content: One August afternoon in 2019, I performed in a short play meant to make incoming freshmen at my college aware of the kinds of challenges they might face during their first year of school. After the lights dimmed on a skit about eating disorders, the topic quickly shifted and the stage opened on a party scene. One thing led to another, and a male cast member whisked me away to his “bedroom” — a few chairs hastily stacked together. We traded clunky dialogue and then he leaned over and said: “I’m really enjoying getting to know you. … Can I kiss you?” As directed, I paused, then enthusiastically blurted out, “OK!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: In ‘The Pink Hotel,’ Delusional Newlyweds Head Toward a Grand Reckoning
description: Liska Jacobs’s novel sets a honeymooning couple in a posh Beverly Hills establishment during a summer of unrest in Los Angeles.
content: One strange element of human behavior is that much of what we call “vacation” involves endlessly tinkering with our body temperatures. Think of the beach. You lie on a towel, grow hot, dip in the ocean to cool down, get out, reheat yourself, dip, cool down, repeat. The joy of recreation can’t be reduced to the fact that it’s really fun to swivel between hot and cold, but signature vacation moments often involve just that: snuggling up to a campfire on a cold night, plunging into a frigid lake on a sweltering afternoon, coming in from the snow to warm up with cocoa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Say Goodbye
description: In Malia Wollan’s final Tip column, some parting advice.
content: “You have to say goodbye in a way that the person will understand,” says Dionne Davis, 45, of Decatur, Ga., who has worked in child care since she was a teenager, first in preschools, and for the last 12 years as a nanny. In that time, she has said goodbye to a lot of children, some of whom she has cared for since birth. Choose words that honor the relationship and its context. “I would never say to a child, ‘I’m not going to work here anymore,’” Davis says. “I would say, ‘Miss Dionne is sad because I won’t get to play with you every day.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Carl Zimmer
title: A fourth Covid vaccine is cleared for use in the United States.
description: The shots from Novavax are only for people who have not yet been vaccinated, which is likely to limit their uptake at first.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday recommended that a newly authorized vaccine from Novavax be used as an option for adults seeking a primary immunization against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Raux Gunther
title: 5 Great Restaurants to Visit in Basque Country
description: Álvaro Garrido, the chef of the Michelin-starred Mina restaurant and a Bilbao native, shares five favorite restaurants that exemplify the resilient spirit of Spain’s northern autonomous region.
content: In Basque Country, the pandemic has served as a reminder of the extent to which food forms the fabric of local life. Eating well is a priority throughout Spain’s northern autonomous community, and seems, to some local chefs, even more so now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beandrea July
title: ‘Aftershock’ Review: A Moving Ode to the Black Family
description: Black mothers are dying from childbirth at alarming rates. A new documentary explains why.
content: There’s no getting around just how terribly sad it feels watching “Aftershock,” the new documentary from the directors Paula Eiselt (“93Queen”) and Tonya Lewis Lee. After all, it spotlights the tragic deaths of two Black mothers in New York City who died from childbirth-related complications — Shamony Gibson, in 2019, and Amber Isaac, in 2020 — leaving behind young children, partners, families and communities gutted by grief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 9 Recap: Bye Bye Love
description: Kim and Gus make some difficult decisions of the heart. Mike goes on a mission of mercy.
content: Let’s break with tradition and start at the end of this whipsawing episode, which delivers two quick jolts in its closing minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Hey, Is Anybody Watching the Interns?
description: School is out for the summer — but in some cases, so are the bosses.
content: Alex Hyman pictured his summer internship as being one part “Entourage” and one part “The Office”: people screaming into telephones Ari Gold superagent style, others menacing their desk mates as unnervingly as Dwight Schrute did at Dunder Mifflin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar
title: Indian Rupee Hits Weakest Level Ever Against the Dollar
description: The Indian currency has lost about 7 percent of its value against the dollar this year, a victim of higher energy prices and economic uncertainty.
content: The Indian rupee touched the weakest level on record against the dollar on Tuesday, another victim of higher energy prices and a stronger greenback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Two Companies Aim to Beat SpaceX to Mars With ‘Audacious’ Landing
description: Relativity Space, which could launch its first rocket soon, and Impulse Space, founded by a SpaceX veteran, optimistically say that together they can reach the red planet a few years from now.
content: SpaceX could lose the race to send the first private space mission to Mars. Maybe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why California Bans State-Funded Travel to Nearly Half of States
description: A 2016 law banning travel to states with anti-L.G.B.T.Q. policies is in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump National Security Aide Expected to Testify at Jan. 6 Hearing
description: Matthew Pottinger, who resigned on the day of the Capitol riot, is expected to be among those at the prime-time session on Thursday, along with Sarah Matthews, a former deputy press secretary.
content: Matthew Pottinger, who was deputy national security adviser under President Donald J. Trump and the highest-ranking White House official to resign on Jan. 6, 2021, is expected to testify about that day at the House select committee’s prime-time hearing on Thursday, people familiar with the planning said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Outbreaks in China prompt lockdowns and fears of more economic woes.
description: The emergence of more infectious subvariants of the coronavirus has triggered mass quarantines, including 2,000 tourists stranded in a popular beach resort town.
content: More than a dozen Chinese cities are grappling with a spate of Covid-19 outbreaks driven by Omicron subvariants, prompting widespread lockdowns and mass quarantines of millions of people that could worsen China’s slumping economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Eliza Fawcett and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: After Indiana Mall Shooting, One Hero but No Lasting Solution
description: When a bystander fatally shot an assailant at an Indiana mall, the country again debated the wisdom of easier access to guns.
content: It was an act of pluck and composure worthy of a scene in the movies. But this was real life: A heavily armed man emerged from the bathroom in a Greenwood, Ind., shopping mall on Sunday evening and began shooting — until he was killed by an armed bystander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Here’s a secret about your neighbors
description: Many of us avoid talking about climate change because it feels so controversial. In fact, research shows that your neighbors are probably thinking about it, too.
content: Merciless heat is scorching much of Europe this month, with temperatures also hitting dangerous levels in parts of Asia and the Americas. It’s one of those times when global warming feels as undeniable as it feels scary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Bodega Clerk Who Fatally Stabbed Man Will Not Face Charges
description: Alvin Bragg, Manhattan’s district attorney, said a murder charge against Jose Alba could not be proved. Mr. Alba’s supporters said he acted in self-defense.
content: After weeks of mounting pressure, the Manhattan district attorney on Tuesday morning dropped a murder charge against a bodega clerk who fatally stabbed an attacker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Commissioner Rejects Idea That Minor Leaguers Aren’t Paid Fairly
description: The league recently agreed to settle a wage dispute, but Rob Manfred cited recent “strides” in compensation. A player advocacy group called Manfred’s statement “callous and false.”
content: LOS ANGELES — Asked why Major League Baseball’s team owners do not pay minor league players a living wage — whether it was because they could not afford to or because they didn’t want to — M.L.B. Commissioner Rob Manfred suggested those players were actually compensated fairly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Hasbro reports rising sales on strong demand, despite higher prices.
description: The toymaker was able to raise prices to offset higher costs, but its revenue took a hit overseas because of a strong dollar.
content: Despite higher prices, people continued to spend on Nerf blasters, Power Rangers action figures and Magic the Gathering cards, helping Hasbro overcome rising costs for materials and freight, the company said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Scenes of Devastation Emerge From a Fire-Ravaged Southwestern France
description: Two wildfires have ravaged nearly 80 square miles of forests, forcing 37,000 people to evacuate. The flames were fanned by a heat wave also feeding blazes in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
content: LA TESTE-DE-BUCH, France — As firefighters battled raging wildfires for the eighth consecutive day in southwest France, scenes of devastation emerged from the ashes, underscoring yet another facet of the disastrous effects of the heat wave currently sweeping Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Ritzi Jacobi, Maker of Mind-Bending Textile Art, Dies at 80
description: Her monumental wall hangings and soft sculptures incorporated fiber-based materials, like goat hair, as part of a “new tapestry” movement.
content: Ritzi Jacobi, a European pioneer of contemporary textile and fiber art who was best known for her monumental wall hangings and soft sculptures, died on June 19 at her home in Düsseldorf, Germany. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ann Shulgin, Who Explored Psychedelics With Her Husband, Dies at 91
description: The couple advocated the use of hallucinogens in psychotherapy and documented their experiences with hundreds of drugs in two widely read books.
content: Ann Shulgin, who alongside her husband, Alexander Shulgin, developed and experimented with hundreds of psychedelic drugs that he concocted in his California laboratory, then showed readers how to formulate them in a pair of massive books that attracted a cult following, died on July 9 at her home near Lafayette, Calif. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Maggie Haberman
title: Secret Service Says Some Missing Jan. 6 Texts Are Unlikely to Be Recovered
description: The House committee investigating the attack on the Capitol had subpoenaed text messages from the agents’ phones and other materials.
content: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service said it may not be able to recover a batch of erased text messages from phones used by its agents around the time of the attack on the Capitol last year, a development that comes amid intensified scrutiny over lapses in the agency’s accounting of its actions during the riots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Intelligence Agencies Say Russia Election Threat Persists Amid Ukraine War
description: Top F.B.I. and National Security Agency officials said that Iran and China also remained potent threats, mounting their own campaigns to undermine American democracy.
content: Top national security officials warned on Tuesday about the continuing threat of election interference from abroad, emphasizing that Russia could still seek to meddle or promote disinformation during the 2022 midterm races even as it wages war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Quarterback Known as ‘AR-15’ Changes Nickname, Citing Mass Shootings
description: Anthony Richardson, a sophomore quarterback and rising star at the University of Florida, asked people to call him “AR” or not use a nickname at all.
content: Anthony Richardson, a University of Florida quarterback known as “AR-15” for his initials and his uniform number, has announced he is embracing a less violent image as he heads into a season in which he is projected to be one of the top players in college football.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Long Ago, I Bought a Human Skull. What Should I Do With It?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on making commercial use of a person’s remains.
content: In the 1970s, as a middle-school science teacher, I bought a preserved human skull from an educational-supply company. I did so in part for my own and my students’ education and wonderment, and in part to have a fascinating conversation piece that I could put on my mantel. At the time, this was entirely legal. Since then, statutes have oscillated between permitting this commerce in human remains and outlawing it, though it has remained largely legal. Of course, there are now excellent plastic replicas available too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: This Political Neophyte Is a Lock for Congress. His Name Helps.
description: Rob Menendez Jr., 37, is running his first race for office for a New Jersey congressional seat that his father, Senator Bob Menendez, once held.
content: Brian Varela’s odds of winning the Democratic congressional primary against the son of a powerful United States senator were always exceedingly long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Stephanie Saul
title: Some Students Want Colleges to Provide the Abortion Pill. Schools Are Resisting.
description: Even in states that protect abortion rights, colleges are proceeding with caution.
content: Many colleges pride themselves on providing a range of sexual and reproductive health services for their students, including birth control, screenings for sexually transmitted diseases and even insurance coverage to terminate a pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Samuel Aranda
title: Where Dalí Once Painted the Sea, Wind Turbines Are Set to Rise
description: Contentious plans to erect a wind farm off the northeastern coast of Spain are part of a tense debate over where to locate new renewable energy projects across Europe.
content: PORT LLIGAT, Spain — Moises Tibau clambered aboard his small wooden boat at dawn, pushing off from a craggy outcropping in front of the house where Salvador Dalí composed some of his most famous Surrealist paintings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Comparisons to Britain’s Summer of 1976 Abound. They’re Misleading.
description: Nostalgic memories of a long hot spell decades ago have become part of the currency of political debate.
content: LONDON — The sun beat down, the reservoirs dried up and, as a minister was appointed to deal with the drought, Britons were urged to restrict their ablutions to just five inches of bath water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Dana Canedy, Publisher of Simon & Schuster’s Flagship Imprint, Has Left the Job
description: She was the first Black woman in the position, which she held for two years. Her hiring came amid a push for diversity in the industry.
content: Dana Canedy, the first Black woman to serve as publisher of Simon & Schuster’s flagship imprint, left her position after two years, the company said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coco Romack
title: From Adam Pendleton, Pancakes That Taste Like Perfection
description: When it comes to cooking, the artist brings an attention to detail he normally saves for his studio practice.
content: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Fight Over Tearing Down a Landmark Red Church
description: West Park Presbyterian Church has been on the Upper West Side for almost 150 years. Now its congregation consists of 12 people.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Tonight’s All-Star Game means we’re halfway through the baseball season, and the Yankees and the Mets are in first place. We’ll see what one of our sports editors has to say about a Subway Series in October. But first we’ll look at a landmark church on the Upper West Side that is seeking permission to demolish its nearly 140-year-old structure for an apartment building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Soaring Overdose Rates in the Pandemic Reflected Widening Racial Disparities
description: A new federal report found that fatal overdoses jumped 44 percent among Black people, twice the increase among white people, from 2019 to the end of 2020.
content: The pandemic’s devastating impact on drug overdose deaths in the United States hit people of color the hardest, with rates among young Black people rising the most sharply, according to a federal report that was released on Tuesday and that analyzed overdose data by race, age and income.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Muted Warnings as Virus Surges Across Country
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 19, 2022.
content: “You don’t have to count every raindrop to know it’s raining. And it’s pouring right now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Mocks Joe Biden for That Fist Bump
description: Noah called the president’s choice how to greet Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia “the whitest decision of all time.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Beutler
title: The Republican Ticket Is Being Helped by the Last People You’d Expect
description: The Republican Party isn’t capable of governing a democracy. And yet Democrats keep helping some of its most unhinged candidates.
content: Three simple facts will form the backdrop of the November midterms, and taken together, they are difficult to fully reconcile: First, Democrats are serious underdogs and may be defeated in a wave as devastating as the ones that wiped them out in 1994 and 2010. Second, Donald Trump, the undisputed leader of the Republican Party, has endorsed a slate of G.O.P. primary candidates who are unfit to hold public office in a democracy. Third, Democrats want to help him get those dangerous loyalists nominated to the Republican ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain’s record-breaking heat comes amid a closely watched political campaign.
description: Political temperatures also rose on Tuesday as the field of candidates seeking to become Britain’s next prime minister was reduced by one.
content: LONDON — Britain’s record-breaking heat wave came against the backdrop of an intensely watched national political contest, as the race to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson was winnowed to just candidates ahead of a critical vote on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Elon Musk and Twitter will go to trial over their $44 billion deal in October.
description: Twitter had sought to expedite the case by requesting a trial in September, which Mr. Musk had countered by asking for a trial in February.
content: Twitter and Elon Musk will go to trial in October over whether the billionaire must complete his $44 billion acquisition of the social media company, a Delaware judge ruled on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Novic
title: Silence Brought Me a Community and an Escape
description: Society maintains that I am broken because of my deafness. I consider myself fortunate to have been given this ability to turn off the sound.
content: Every evening when I return home, I rush into my house and rip my hearing aids out of my head. No matter where I’ve been, the routine is the same. Sometimes I’m in such a hurry I can’t even stand to cycle through the settings on the power button, so I pop open the battery doors instead. Then I stash them on a high bookshelf out of reach of my toddler, where they stay until the next time I venture out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bijan Stephen
title: Landscape Mode
description: Elvia Wilk’s essay collection is “fan nonfiction” that takes on myriad kinds of world-building.
content: Landscapes invite contemplation. Natural or built, eerie or spectacular, they’re spaces to project ourselves into. What if I lived there in the woods? What kind of person would I be if I lived by that seaside? What if I leaped off this cliff?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Europe’s Heat Wave Shatters British Records and Drives Wildfires
description: Europe is ill prepared for extreme heat fed by global warming. For the first time on record, parts of Britain hit 40 degrees Celsius — 104 Fahrenheit — as did Paris for only the third time.
content: LONDON — For the first time on record, Britain suffered under temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius — 104 Fahrenheit — on Tuesday, as a ferocious heat wave moved northwest, leaving a trail of raging wildfires, lost lives and evacuated homes across a Europe frighteningly ill-equipped to cope with the new reality of extreme weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Maggie Haberman
title: Bennie Thompson, chairman of the Jan. 6 panel, has tested positive for the coronavirus.
description: Mr. Thompson will not join his colleagues at a scheduled prime time hearing on Thursday, though he instructed the committee to move forward as planned.
content: Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, the chairman of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the United States Capitol, announced on Tuesday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus and will not appear in person at what could be the committee’s last hearing of the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Sashay Away!
description: An erstwhile influencer from Fiji clocked 28 million page views with a homemade video of him strutting a runway wearing a ladder, a bench and other household goods.
content: It has been two weeks or an internet eternity since Shaheel Sanil Prasad, a.k.a. Shaheel Shermont Flair, a former call center agent and part-time influencer from Suva City in central Fiji, posted one of the funniest catwalk videos ever to hit social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Diana Nguyen, Will Reid, M.J. Davis Lin, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Broken Climate Pledges and Europe’s Heat Wave
description: Has the era of global cooperation over planet-warming emissions ended?
content: A record-breaking heat wave is currently washing over Europe. In parts of Britain, the mercury has hit a freakishly high 100 degrees Fahrenheit or more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Says It Lost Nearly 1 Million Subscribers, and Breathes a Sigh of Relief
description: The streaming giant, facing significant headwinds, had said it expected to lose two million subscribers in the second quarter.
content: Disaster has been averted at Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: The Cost of Extreme Heat
description: Britain this morning recorded its highest temperature ever, bringing parts of the country to a standstill and testing infrastructure.
content: The European heat wave that baked Italy, France and Spain over the past week has reached London, putting life on hold and testing infrastructure. Britain this morning recorded its highest temperature ever, as the heat led some schools, museums and doctors’ offices to close, and some trains and flights to be canceled. Forecasters reported temperatures of 40 degrees Celsius, or 104 degrees Fahrenheit, today in London. Officials issued Britain’s first “red” warning for extreme heat, declaring a national emergency in a country accustomed to temperate weather, where few homes have air conditioning. In the U.S., President Biden reportedly may declare a climate emergency as soon as this week, according to The Washington Post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eilene Zimmerman
title: Can a ‘Magic’ Protein Slow the Aging Process?
description: Elevian is one of several companies searching for ways to increase life span — in this case, using a protein called GDF11. But challenges lie ahead.
content: This article is part of Upstart, a series about young companies harnessing new science and technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Olson
title: Russia fines Google for failing to remove news it calls ‘fake.’
description: A Russian court fined Google about $360 million (21.1 billion rubles) on Monday for failing to remove content the country deems illegal, including coverage of the war in Ukraine.
content: A Russian court fined Google about $360 million (21.1 billion rubles) on Monday for failing to remove content the country deems illegal, including coverage of the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Abortion Provider Prepares Defamation Suit Against Indiana Attorney General
description: The doctor in the case of a 10-year-old rape victim says the attorney general acted with “reckless disregard of the truth.” A spokesman calls the claims “baseless.”
content: An Indianapolis doctor who provided abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim is preparing to sue Attorney General Todd Rokita of Indiana for defamation after he said he would investigate her actions in the case, according to a statement released on Tuesday by her lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Inflation: A Revolution of Falling Expectations
description: Surprising hints that this may turn out OK.
content: Macroeconomic policy in the United States has been subject to two great errors over the past half-century. The odds are that you’ve only heard about the first, the way the Federal Reserve allowed inflation to become entrenched in the 1970s. But the second — the way policymakers allowed the economy to operate far below capacity, needlessly sacrificing millions of potential jobs, for a decade following the financial crisis — was arguably even more severe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: The Burger J. Kenji López-Alt Can’t Improve (Only Tweak)
description: Oklahoma onion burgers, which cook in moments, are so perfect in their simplicity that they can’t be better, he writes.
content: Humans have been cooking meat with onions for at least as long as recipes have been recorded, but I’d argue that the combination was simplified to its primal core during the Great Depression, when Homer Davis and his son Ross invented what they called the Depression burger at the Hamburger Inn in El Reno, Okla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Maryland’s primary election results are expected to be delayed.
description: Maryland is the only state that prohibits mail-in ballots from being processed until after the election, a prepandemic rule that lawmakers were unsuccessful in changing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 4: On ‘The Real Reason the Minions Have Taken Over the World’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Claire Guo, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
content: We received 1,059 entries from students from around the world for the fourth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Claire Guo, as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aliza Abarbanel
title: On Long Island’s South Shore, a Leisurely Summer Dinner
description: The chef Andy Baraghani took a break from his cookbook tour to share some of the dishes featured in its pages with friends.
content: I’m one step through the doorway of Andy Baraghani’s kitchen and suddenly the air is perfumed with peonies, earthy dill and just-fried onions. The chef and food writer, 32, is eager to play with the first tastes of summer but is also determined to let the season’s bounty speak largely for itself. “I want my cooking to be effortless, and this time of year, you don’t have to do too much,” he says, popping a strawberry into his mouth and grinning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: It Looks Awkward, but This Fish Has a Secret Glow
description: Lumpy, but brilliant under UV light.
content: What color is a lumpfish? The answer is more complicated than you might expect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Joe Manchin Is a Symptom, but It’s the Senate That’s Sick
description: It’s no accident that climate legislation has repeatedly been passed in the House only to collapse in the Senate.
content: Seventy-two percent of likely voters, according to the left-leaning polling group Data for Progress, want the federal government to increase its tax incentives for solar, wind and other clean energy projects. Sixty-nine percent of likely voters want the government to take steps to make electric vehicles more affordable for more people. And 60 percent of likely voters support policies that would regulate carbon emissions and force power plants to clean up their act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: How to Spend a Day in Brighton Beach
description: By car, bike or train, you owe yourself a beach trip powered by khachapuri.
content: I like to say that New York City is famously a beach town. It certainly has more beach access than where I grew up — landlocked metro Atlanta; that you can get to most of these beaches by subway, bus, bike or ferry is even better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Money Managers Are in a ‘Dire’ Mood, Poll Finds
description: Investors surveyed by Bank of America have never been more pessimistic about the economic outlook.
content: Investors are hoarding cash and lowering their expectations for growth, as pessimism about the outlook for the U.S. economy has reached a “dire” level, according to a survey of 259 fund managers responsible for more than $700 billion in investments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Vacations Bar & Rooftop, With Tropical Drinks, Opens in Bushwick, Brooklyn
description: An elegant French restaurant from a Benoit alumnus, an Italian West Village spot from a family of restaurateurs, and more restaurant news.
content: New York is blessed with rooftops galore for drinks and dining amid stupendous views.  Given a felicitous location, even the second floor will do as at this sprawling new bar in Bushwick, Brooklyn, with the Manhattan skyline as its backdrop. Come September, the building below will be turned into an all-seasons restaurant; for now, there is a bar on the rooftop, with a  second coming soon. (A third will be located downstairs.) It has a tropical influence, with greenery, weathered wood, green tiles, chessboard stone flooring and blue walls. Drinks and food are self-service, to order at the bar, with choices like fried smashed fingerling potatoes with aioli and brava sauce, shrimp cocktail, fish and chips, and a broccoli rabe hero. Drinks, all $12, include a Tropicale, made with Meyer lemon vodka, passion fruit liqueur, lime and guava juice; and the Proposal, made with pineapple rum, lime and simple syrup. Vantage Point Hospitality owns and runs Vacations with Annie and Andy Shaner, restaurant veterans who live in the neighborhood.

content: The U.S. Marshals Service this week announced a $5,000 reward for information that leads to the capture of a 19-year-old man who was charged last year with stealing two of Lady Gaga’s French bulldogs and shooting her dog walker — but was accidentally released from a Los Angeles jail in April.

content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Andy Kravis is an excellent multipurpose constructor.
